repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
We lost the type when optimising the numeric operation, thus generating less optimal C code further on.

PyFloat is used in object operations, e.g. when `None` is allowed.

comment_data.body: Would `float | None` work for what you're really trying to test here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -167,3 +167,36 @@ def global_floats():
     nan
     """
     return (cdef_float_nan, cdef_float_infp, cdef_float_infn)
+
+
+def truthy_float(x: float):

@@ -167,3 +167,36 @@ def global_floats():
     nan
     """
     return (cdef_float_nan, cdef_float_infp, cdef_float_infn)
+
+
+def truthy_float(x: float):

commit.message:
Infer PyLong/PyFloat types across optimised operations.

PyFloat isn't really used anywhere since it's always aliased as C double, but it can't hurt to include it for object operations.
Extend tests and make sure we test with a Python float and not a C double.
Use actual builtin return type also for the substituted C function type to make it visible to the caller.
Assume that the optimised function never returns None if we know the return type.

title: Infer PyLong/PyFloat types across optimised operations
